name: chicagotribune
text:
Here are today’s top stories in Chicago-area politics, from @byldonovan:

• Mayor Lightfoot pleads for calm
• Despite unrest, Chicago "will reopen tomorrow," mayor says
• Sen. Duckworth blasts Trump as "draft dodging wannabe tin-pot dictator" https://t.co/vcqZtz5hMz

name: chicagotribune
text: Following days of unrest, Mayor Lightfoot calls on Chicago to “stand for peace” and promises to enact a series of long-stalled police reforms. https://t.co/pSqHZXRIIO

name: chicagotribune
text: Officials in Cicero encouraged peaceful protesters but urged others to stay indoors Tuesday night after looters clashed with both police officers and armed vigilantes and two men were shot dead Monday https://t.co/K3UJSrPA4R

name: chicagotribune
text: A new “cocktails to go” law in Illinois allows bars and restaurants with liquor licenses to sell adult beverages for delivery and pickup. But changes to Chicago's municipal code are required before delivery service can begin within city limits. https://t.co/dRFF7HBqFO

name: chicagotribune
text:
Outside a smoldering building on Monday, three friends spent the afternoon sweeping up glass and litter scattered by looters the night before. 

“You’ve got to send a message to everybody that you’re not going to give up,” Malcolm Cherry said. https://t.co/tItH6eCOAu

name: chicagotribune
text: Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot promised to enact a series of police reforms and announced a $10 million grant fund to help looted businesses, as she called on Chicagoans to “stand for peace” in the wake of days of unrest across the city and the nation https://t.co/vcj0hqh3lr

name: chicagotribune
text:
“We live in apocalyptic times, but what kind of consciousness do we develop to live through that? ... Right now, I have a heavy heart, a physical pain. Poetry will be a way to metabolize that pain.”

Chicago poet Rosanna Warren on writing in this moment: https://t.co/87qDcutAXs

name: chicagotribune
text: Where do we go from here? Martin Luther King Jr.’s old question endures, writes columnist @cptime. https://t.co/6sFRNzBgTS

name: chicagotribune
text: Mayor Lightfoot is pushing ahead with plans to allow businesses to start gradually reopening Wednesday. But how much of Chicago actually opens back up will vary by neighborhood. https://t.co/6L9hU2ceIk

name: chicagotribune
text: Downtown Chicago will begin to reopen Wednesday, with lowered bridges and resumed Metra and CTA service. https://t.co/AhMQLM8g1L

name: chicagotribune
text: Downtown Chicago will begin to reopen Wednesday, with lowered bridges and resumed Metra and CTA service. https://t.co/QUHZtbxrhF

name: chicagotribune
text: In a speech on Tuesday evening, Mayor Lightfoot promised to enact a series of long-stalled police reforms and announced a $10 million grant fund for looted businesses. https://t.co/ISWKJXU4sL

name: chicagotribune
text:
"We live in apocalyptic times, but what kind of consciousness do we develop to live through that? ... Right now, I have a heavy heart, a physical pain. Poetry will be a way to metabolize that pain."

Chicago poet Rosanna Warren on writing in this moment: https://t.co/nIGUFsEaBF

name: chicagotribune
text: Does the 1968 election offer hope for President Trump? Not likely. If that tumultuous year tells us anything, it's that when things go seriously wrong, the people in charge take the fall, writes columnist @SteveChapman13. https://t.co/JuGE89xe8w

name: chicagotribune
text: After days of road closures and reduced transit service, access to downtown Chicago will start to reopen this morning. https://t.co/qssToRCjpS

name: chicagotribune
text:
“We need to work together to dismantle racism.”

Latino activists speak out about racial tension with black Chicagoans on the city's Southwest Side amid the George Floyd fallout. https://t.co/I0iT6U2Srs

name: chicagotribune
text: Good morning, Chicago. The city starts reopening today despite unrest and COVID-19 concerns. Here’s what you need to know. https://t.co/qEpwAHNTWn
